Copper nanoparticles decorated on boron nitride nanoflakes as an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of propargylamines under green conditions Fardin Ghasemy Piranloo a ⁎ Mahshid Kazemi Abharian a Fatimah Kavousi a Rafael Luque b c a Biosphere Technology Company, Abhar-zanjan, Iran Biosphere Technology Company Abhar-zanjan Iran aBiosphere Technology Company, Abhar-zanjan, Iran b Departamento de Química Orgánica, Universidad de Córdoba, Campus de Rabanales, Edificio Marie Curie (C-3), Ctra. Single or multilayer boron nitride nanoflakes (BNNSs), known as white graphite, due to their have various technological applications unique properties such as mechanical stability, high thermal stability and chemical inertness. In this study, copper (Cu) nanoparticles (NPs) were successfully uniformly attached on BNSS surface by precipitation process. The morphology, composition, and chemical structure of modified BNNS were carefully identified by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption–desorption, elemental mapping and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX), UV–vis absorption spectra, and atomic force microscopy (AFM). It was observed that the Cu/BNSs displayed excellent catalytic activity and recyclability for the generation of diverse propargylamines at mild conditions of three component reaction of aldehydes, amines, and alkynes. It also demonstrates that BNNSs act as efficient support to generate heterogeneous catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Copper nanoparticles Boron nitride nanoflakes Green conditions Propargylamines Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Propargylamine compounds have been widely known as beneficial building blocks for pharmacological and pharmaceutical chemistry [1,2]. Propargylamine derivatives such as rasagiline [3], pargyline [4], and selegiline [5] have wide applications in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's [6,7]. In traditional methods, these derivatives are made from the reaction between lithium acetylides or Grignard reagents as nucleophiles and imines or their derivatives. However, these reagents are very sensitive to moisture and require controlled reaction conditions [8–10]. Due to the importance of these compounds, various synthetic methods and homogeneous and heterogeneous based on transition-metal catalysts for the production of these compounds were proposed [11,12]. An important and easy method compared to the traditional methods for the synthesis of propargylamine derivatives is the catalyzed reaction of an aldehyde, amine, and alkene (A3-coupling) in which the activation of a terminal alkyne C–H bond in the presence of transition-metal [9,13–17]. In recent years, there has been extensive research to develop transition-metal catalysts such as Ag [18], Au [19], Fe [20], Cu [21,22], Zn [23], and nickel [24] for the catalytic generation of metal acetylides under mild reaction conditions for propargylamines production. However, due to the cheapness, availability, and high reactivity of copper precursors, many A3 coupling reactions have been reported in the presence of homogeneous and heterogeneous copper catalysts. As mentioned, since propargylamines are widely used in pharmacological and pharmaceutical chemistry, contamination of the product with the toxic metal is not desirable. So, Heterogeneous transition-metal catalysis allows the separation and recycling of catalysts, easy purification of the product, and the possibility of continuous or multiple processing of compounds. In this regard, Cu catalysts stabilized on the surface of various solid supports, such as, SiO2 [25], mesoporous Cu/Al [26], zeolites [27], metal–organic framework [28] , and Fe3O4 [29,30] have been reported for A3 coupling through the activation of terminal alkyne C–H bonds. BNNSs have been extensively studied for a variety of technological applications such as catalyst supports, polymeric nanocomposites, lithium batteries, and electronic devices due to their unique properties including, large surface area chemical inertness, extreme resistance to oxidation, and ultimate electrical insulation [31,32]. Recent studies show that BNNSs are effective supports that facilitates the process of separating the catalyst from the reaction medium after the reaction [33]. For example, Sun and colleagues synthesized BNNSs in thionyl chloride solvent using intense ultrasound waves. Then, decorating Pd nanoscale on the BNNS surface reported an efficient catalyst for the hydrogenation of the nitro-aromatic reaction [34]. Chen et al. have employed Fe/BNNS as an efficient catalyst for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [35]. Fan et al. have prepared few-layer or mono-layer BN sodium hypochlorite ball mill and examined their potential application in catalysis [36]. In this work, we use BNNSs as a new, highly efficient, and excellent nano-sized support for decorating Cu nanoparticles. The strong bond interactions between the Cu and the functional groups present on the BNNS surface provide the ideal center for the A3-coupling reaction. Cu nanoparticles were stabilized on the BNNSs surface using the impregnation method. The produced catalysts were applied in the A3-coupling reaction (Scheme 1 ), and the influence of diverse parameters was examined on the catalyst activity to optimize the reaction conditions. Experimental section Materials All purchased materials were used in the carbonization reaction without purification. Morpholine (purity: 99%), Piperidine (purity: 99%), Benzaldehyde (purity: 99%), Formaldehyde, Copper (II) acetate (purity: 98%), h-BN (purity: 98%), and Sodium borohydride (purity: ≥98%) were bought from Sigma Aldrich company. Fabricate of catalyst Preparation of BNNSs Pristine h-BN was exfoliated according to a previously reported method [37]. In summary, as-supplied pristine h-BN (100 mg) was added to deionized water (50 mL) and sonicated for 8 h. The resulting mixture centrifuged at 3,000 rpm for 10 min. In order to collect boron nitride nanofibers, the zinc liquid was passed through whatman cellulose filter paper and then dried at 70°C for 6 h. Preparation of Cu on BNNSs Typically, 50 mg of BNNSs were added to a round bottom flask containing 20 mL of deionized water and sonicated for 1 h. 0.3 mmol of Cu (OAc)2.H2O which previously dissolved in 5 mL water was added dropwise to the stirring suspension for 15 min stirred for 1 h. Then, .1 mmol of NaBH4 which previously dissolved in 5 mL water was added dropwise to the resulting mixture under nitrogen atmosphere, and reaction mixture stirred at 600 rpm for 12 h at 30°C at room temperature. The obtained catalyst was collected (Cu/BNNS), washed three times with ethanol, and dried in vacuum oven at 70°C for 6 h. Characterisation Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Philips EM208S 100KV) and Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, ZEISS Sigma 300 model) results were obtained. Atomic force microscopy (AFM, AFM, ARA-BRISK) analysis was used to measure the thickness of the synthesized nanosheets. ICP-EOS technique was used to evaluate the amount of Cu nanoparticles stabilized on the BNNS surface. For this purpose, each of samples was dissolved in 3 mL of aqua regia and diluted to the required concentration. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis) absorption spectra were obtained via a LABOMED, UVD-2950 device spectrometer. Apparatus ultrasonic device (Branson 2510, 40 kHz) was used to exfoliate h-BN. Glass chromatography filled with 20-30 gram of silica gel 60 Sigma-Aldrich (230-240 mesh) was used to purify the synthesized propargylamines derivatives using different concentrations of ethyl acetate/ hexanes as eluents. 13C NMR and 1H NMR were obtained in CDCl3 solution with 1% (v/v) TMS as internal standard in a Brucker Advance 250 MHz NMR. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) of samples were collected on a model Philips X'PertPro. In order to study the surface area of the produced samples, the Brunauer-Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis by a Quanta Chrome Corporation Autosorb was used by N2 adsorption-desorption at -196°C. General process for catalytic A3-coupling reactions 10 mg of catalyst was added to the vial flask containing a mixture of phenylacetylene (0.7 mmol), aldehyde (0.5 mmol), amine (0.8 mmol), and 2 mL of deionized water and the mixture was stirred at 50°C for 14 h under nitrogen atmosphere. After the reaction was complete, the vial flask containing the reaction mixture was cooled at room temperature, then the mixture was added to 50 mL of water and extracted with ethyl acetate, this process which was repeated three times. Finally, column chromatography containing silica gel using petroleum hexane /ethyl acetate was applied to purify the products from the reaction mixture. To a solution of Cu/BNNS (10 mg) aldehyde 4 (0.1 mmol), amine (0.22 mmol) and alkyne (0.3 mmol) in water (1 mL) were stirred at 50 °C for 16 h under N2 atmosphere. The reaction mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3 × 15 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The product was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel using ethyl acetate-hexane as eluent. All yields were identified by 1H and 13C NMR. Results and discussion XRD and UV–Vis investigation XRD was employed to examine the crystal structure and phase purity of h-BN, BNNS, and Cu/BNNS samples. According to Fig. 1, Five diffraction peaks at 26.75, 41.55, 43.85, 50.15, and 55.5° were obtained for the pristine h-BN, nd BNNS [38,39]. From the comparison diffraction peaks of h-BN and BNNS, the relative peaks intensity of BNNS are significantly different from that of h-BN. For example, diffraction peaks (002), and (004) are more intense than other diffraction peaks, which indicates the success of the peeling process [40]. For Cu/BNNS catalyst compared to the BNNS support, additional peaks appear in 2ϴ= 36.3, 50.61, and 74.35° can be related the diffractions peaks of (111), (200), and (220), respectively (Fig. 1a) [41,42]. As shown in Fig. 1b, an adsorption peak was recorded at 205 nm for BNNSs, which may be related to the -OH functional groups formed on the BNNS surface during the peeling process [43] Morphological investigation (FE-SEM, TEM, and AFM) FE-SEM was used to investigate the surface morphology of BNSSs. Fig. 2 displayed representative micrographs obtained on exfoliated BN. FE-SEM image of BNNS displays sheet like structures comprising of flat surface (Fig. 1a). TEM analysis was also used to further investigate the microstructures of synthesized samples. In addition to FE-SEM, TEM results of BNNS was also performed which shows sheet like structure with nanometer thickness (Fig. 2 b). Upon deposition of Cu nanoparticles on the BNNS surface, no change in morphology was observed. However, the appearance of dark spots is related to evenly distributed Cu nanoparticles with an average size of ca. 10 nm (Fig. 2 c). AFM technique was used to determine the thickness of the synthesized nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 3, the thickness of two BN nanosheets was calculated to be 4.81 and 7.01 nm, respectively, which corresponds to 5 to 12 layer nanosheets. Textural investigation The porosity and specific surface area of the pristine h-BN, BNNSs, and Cu/BNNS samples were examined via BET technique (Fig. 4). Based on Fig. 4, all samples exhibit a usual type (II) adsorption/desorption isotherms whit hysteresis loop H3 in the P/P0 range of 0.4−1.0 corresponded to the mesoporous structure [41,44,45]. Measured BET surface areas of h-BN, BNNS, and Cu/BNNS samples are calculated to be 11 and 50.2 and 43 m2 /g, respectively. After the stabilization of Cu nanoparticles on BNNSs, the area of BN namosheets has decreased compared to h-BN, These findings indicate that Cu nanoparticles have been successfully immobilized on the BNNSs surface. BJH theory was used to investigate the pore size distribution of the synthesized samples. The average pore sizes for h-BN, BNNS, and Cu/BNNS samples were 16, 36, and 29 nm, respectively. EDX and elemental mapping analysis The output results of EDX and elemental mapping analysis of Cu nanoparticles decorated on BNNS shown in Fig. 5 confirm the presence of Cu element and their uniform distribution on the BNSSs surface. Catalyst tests To investigate the catalytic activity of the synthesized catalyst, a three-component coupling (A3coupling) reaction for the preparation of propargylamines was attempted. The reaction between morpholine, benzaldehyde, and phenyl acetylene catalyst was selected and effect of solvent, amount of catalyst, time, and reaction temperature were examined. The data are presented in Table 1 . The effects of different solvents at room temperature have been investigated. H2O showed better yield compared to other solvents such as toluene, DMF, dioxane, CH3CN, and EtOH (Table 1, entries 1-5). To study the temperature effect and amount of catalyst effect on the results of the reaction, the model reaction was carried out with the different amounts of catalyst of Cu/BNNS and under different temperatures in H2O solvent (Table 1, entries 6-12). It was observed that by increasing the amount of catalyst from 0 mg to 12 mg, the activity of the catalyst for propargylamines production increased. This may be due to the increase in the number of active catalyst sites that interact with C–H bond of the alkyne (Table 1, entries 6-9). Also, with increasing temperature from 25 °C to 100 °C, the reaction efficiency increased from 35 to 98%. To select greener conditions, a temperature of 50°C was chosen, because the production yields of other propargylamines derivatives were approximately identical at 50 and 100°C (Table 1, entries 9-12). According to results presented in Table 1 (entries 12-14), with increasing the reaction time from 5 h to 14 h, the reaction efficiency increased, but at times longer than 14 h, the reaction efficiency did not change. It should be noted that the reaction in the presence of boron nitride nanosheets (no Cu) did not show any catalytic activity (Table 1, entry 15). Reaching optimum reaction conditions, a wide range of different aldehydes containing electron withdrawing and electron-donating substituents were reacted with Phenylacetylene and different bases such as piperidine and morpholine. Results presented in Table 1 show that aromatic aldehydes derivatives containing electron withdrawing and electron-donating groups show high reactivity in the presence of various cyclic amines such as morpholine and piperidine under optimal conditions (Table 2 ). It is noteworthy that aromatic aldehydes containing nitro substations did not achieve the desired product (Table 2, entry 11). With the exception of aromatic aldehydes, heterocyclic aldehydes such as formaldehyde generated the corresponding propargylicamines in excellent yields (Table 2, entry 4). The proposed mechanism for the production of propargylamines from A3 coupling reaction in the presence of Cu/BNNS is depicted in Scheme 2 . The reaction started via C-H bond activation of the terminal alkyne by Cu/BNNS catalyst (Scheme 2, A). The alkynyl-Cu intermediate produced attacks the generated iminium ion (generated by the react of the amine with the activated carbon of the aldehydic group) to generate the corresponding propargylic amine product (Scheme 2, B and C) [46–48]. Recyclability of heterogeneous Cu/BNNS catalysts One of the important and cost-effective features of heterogeneous catalysts compared to homogeneous catalysts is the ability to recycle and reuse them. The ability to reuse Cu/BNNS in the reaction between morpholine, benzaldehyde, and phenyl acetylene under optimized reaction conditions was investigated. After the reaction in each step, the reaction mixture was centrifuged to separate the catalyst, and the isolated catalyst was washed three times with ethanol and used in the next run. The results showed that this catalyst can be recycled and reused up to 6 runs (Fig. 6 ). Conclusions BNNS was employed as an efficient and versatile nanosheet-sized substrate for the stabilization of Cu nanoparticles. The strong bond interactions between copper and the functional groups created on the surface and edges of BNNSs provided optimum geometry and electron status for the A3-coupling reaction between phenylacetylene and aldehydes to achieve the desired products in excellent yields. Cu/BNNS catalyst was recyclable and reusable up to six runs without significant deactivation. Finally, the catalyst reported in this study does not contain noble, heavy or toxic metals, opening up real opportunities for practical application. It also paves the way for the development of heterogeneous catalysts based on boron nitride nanoflakes. coredata.dc:description: Single or multilayer boron nitride nanoflakes (BNNSs), known as white graphite, due to their have various technological applications unique properties such as mechanical stability, high thermal stability and chemical inertness. In this study, copper (Cu) nanoparticles (NPs) were successfully uniformly attached on BNSS surface by precipitation process. The morphology, composition, and chemical structure of modified BNNS were carefully identified by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption–desorption, elemental mapping and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX), UV–vis absorption spectra, and atomic force microscopy (AFM). It was observed that the Cu/BNSs displayed excellent catalytic activity and recyclability for the generation of diverse propargylamines at mild conditions of three component reaction of aldehydes, amines, and alkynes. It also demonstrates that BNNSs act as efficient support to generate heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Copper nanoparticles decorated on boron nitride nanoflakes as an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of propargylamines under green conditions
